pageContext.claim: “We have -- the poverty numbers -- it's a poverty scale -- and the African Americans doing the best that they've ever done in the history of our country.”
pageContext.analysis: Scholars increasingly believe that the official poverty estimate is somewhat misleading and not especially informative. This is in large part because transfer payments — such as the earned-income tax credit or food stamps — are not recorded as income, so their impact isn’t incorporated into the official figure. To assuage these concerns, the Census Bureau introduced a second poverty measure in 2011 — the Supplemental Poverty Measure. For African Americans, the SPM's lowest point was in 2016 with a slight uptick in 2017. Plus, according to 2017 data, the median income for African Americans is still lower than it was in 2000, though these data do not yet include the impact of Trump’s tax cut.
